title: Judgment and Exile Pronounced
shortSummary: Jeremiah 25 records the prophet's long ministry warning Judah of impending judgment due to their persistent disobedience. God declares that Nebuchadnezzar, king of Babylon, will bring destruction and exile upon Judah and surrounding nations for seventy years as a consequence of their rebellion. The chapter emphasizes God's sovereignty, justice, and the certainty of His prophetic word.
timeline: c. 605 BC - Early Babylonian period during Jehoiakim's reign in Judah

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who delivers God's message of judgment and exile to Judah and the surrounding nations.

keyCharacters.name: Jehoiakim
keyCharacters.description: King of Judah during whose reign Jeremiah receives this prophecy; represents the disobedient leadership of Judah.

keyCharacters.name: Nebuchadrezzar
keyCharacters.description: King of Babylon, God's appointed instrument to execute judgment on Judah and other nations.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: King of Egypt mentioned as one of the nations subject to God's judgment.

definitions.definition: The powerful Babylonian king who conquered Judah and led the exile, serving as God's instrument of judgment.
A metaphor for God's wrath and judgment poured out upon the nations for their sins.
The period of Babylonian domination and exile prophesied by Jeremiah, symbolizing a divinely appointed time of punishment.
A state of ruin and emptiness resulting from divine judgment, often involving destruction of cities and loss of life.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Long Ministry and Judah’s Rejection
outline.description: Jeremiah recounts his prophetic ministry beginning in Josiah's reign, emphasizing Judah’s persistent refusal to repent despite repeated warnings from God’s prophets.

outline.heading: God’s Judgment Announced: Babylon’s Coming
outline.description: God declares that because of Judah’s disobedience, He will send Nebuchadnezzar and the northern nations to bring destruction and exile, resulting in seventy years of servitude.

outline.heading: The Wine Cup of God’s Wrath Poured Out on Nations
outline.description: Jeremiah is commanded to make all nations drink from the cup of God's fury, symbolizing universal judgment against Judah and surrounding peoples.

outline.heading: The Certainty of Judgment and Its Global Scope
outline.description: God warns that refusal to accept judgment will not prevent punishment; a great calamity will sweep the earth, and the slain will be unburied, showing the severity of divine justice.

outline.heading: The Shepherds’ Doom and the Land’s Desolation
outline.description: The leaders (shepherds) of Judah will face destruction with no escape, and the land will become desolate due to God’s fierce anger against the oppressors.

application: Heed God’s warnings promptly and repent from sin to avoid the consequences of disobedience.
Recognize that God’s judgment is just and certain, and trust in His sovereign plan even amid difficult circumstances.
Commit to faithful obedience and prayer, knowing that persistent rebellion leads to spiritual and national ruin.
Encourage others with the truth of God’s justice and mercy, calling them to turn back to Him before it is too late.

keyVerses.text: And this whole land shall be a desolation, and an astonishment; and these nations shall serve the king of Babylon seventy years.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the duration and severity of the Babylonian exile as a direct consequence of Judah’s sin.

keyVerses.text: For thus saith the LORD God of Israel unto me; Take the wine cup of this fury at my hand, and cause all the nations, to whom I send thee, to drink it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse symbolizes God’s universal judgment against sin, showing His control over all nations.

keyVerses.text: For, lo, I begin to bring evil on the city which is called by my name, and should ye be utterly unpunished? Ye shall not be unpunished: for I will call for a sword upon all the inhabitants of the earth, saith the LORD of hosts.
keyVerses.significance: God’s judgment begins with Jerusalem, emphasizing that no one escapes His righteous justice.

keyVerses.text: He hath forsaken his covert, as the lion: for their land is desolate because of the fierceness of the oppressor, and because of his fierce anger.
keyVerses.significance: This verse vividly portrays God’s withdrawal of protection due to persistent sin, resulting in desolation.
